natural problem: Add $4_6 + 14_6.$ Express your answer in base $6.$
natural solution: When adding the numbers, we notice that $4+4$ leaves a residue of $2$ when divided by $6.$ Thus, the sum will have a rightmost digit of $2,$ and we must carry-over. This yields that $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c} & & & \stackrel{1}{} & \stackrel{}{4}_6 \\ &+ & & 1 & 4_6 \\ \cline{2-5} && & 2 & 2_6 \\ \end{array}$$ The sum is therefore $\boxed{22_6}.$

 *)

fixes a b :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "a = numeral (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One))"
and h1 : "b = numeral (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit1 Num.One)))"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = int_of_digitlist_base (rev [4]) 6"
and h1 : "b = int_of_digitlist_base (rev [1, 4]) 6"
shows  "digitlist_base_of_int 6 (a + b) = rev [2, 2]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

assumes h0 : "a = int_of_digitlist_base (rev [4]) 6"
and h1 : "b = int_of_digitlist_base (rev [1, 4]) 6"
shows  "digitlist_base_of_int 6 (a + b) = rev [2, 2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
